skills.name: Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place
Convert terminating decimals less than 1 with 1 decimal place to fractions
Convert terminating decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal places to fractions
Convert terminating decimals less than 1 with 3 or more decimal places to fractions

explanations.A: This would be the fraction for 0.09 as that has 9 in the hundredths column. What place value column does the decimal 0.9 have the 9 in?
explanations.B: We need to use our knowledge of place value columns to answer this question. Looking at the decimal 0.9 we can see there is a 9 in the tenths column, this shows us we have 9/10.
explanations.C: Think about your place value columns.. There are tens, units, tenths, hundredths etc. The number 0.9 has what number in what place value column?
explanations.D: Think about your place value columns.. There are tens, units, tenths, hundredths etc. The number 0.9 has what number in what place value column?

explanations.A: Think about your place value columns.. There are tens, units, tenths, hundredths etc. The number 0.3 has what number in what place value column?
explanations.B: Think about your place value columns.. There are tens, units, tenths, hundredths etc. The number 0.3 has what number in what place value column?
explanations.C: 3/100 would be the fraction for 0.03 as that has 3 in the hundredths column. What place value column does the decimal 0.3 have the 3 in?
explanations.D: We need to use our knowledge of place value columns to answer this question. Looking at the decimal 0.3 we can see there is a 3 in the tenths column, this shows us we have 3/10.

explanations.A: This would be the same as 7 wholes and 1 tenth (7 and 1/10). We have 7/10. Think about your place value columns, how many units do we have? How many tenths do we have? Fill in the numbers to get your decimal.
explanations.B: This is the decimal for 7/100. You have put a 7 in the hundredths column but we need to put a 7 in the tenths column as we have 7/10.
explanations.C: This is the decimal for 7 wholes (7/1). Think about your place value columns, how many units do we have? How many tenths do we have? Fill in the numbers to get your decimal.
explanations.D: The fraction shown is 7/10. Thinking about place value columns: we have no units so we put a 0 in the units column and the first column after the decimal point is the tenths, we have 7 of them so we write 0.7.

explanations.A: This is the decimal for 9 wholes (9/1). To turn this into a decimal use the fact that the fraction line means divide.
explanations.B: The fraction shown is 9/10. Thinking about place value columns: we have no units so we put a 0 in the units column and the first column after the decimal point is the tenths, we have 9 of them so we write 0.9.
explanations.C: This would be the same as 9 wholes and 1 tenth (9 and 1/10). We have 9/10. Think about your place value columns, how many units do we have? How many tenths do we have? Fill in the numbers to get your decimal.
explanations.D: This is the decimal for 9/100. You have put a 9 in the hundredths column but we need to put a 9 in the tenths column as we have 9/10.

explanations.A: Not quite, remember that we are asked for any fraction that is equivalent to 0.8. Use the place value to write it as a fraction, and see if Tom or Katie have an answer equivalent to that.
explanations.B: Not quite, remember that we are asked for any fraction that is equivalent to 0.8. Use the place value to write it as a fraction, and see if Tom or Katie have an answer equivalent to that.
explanations.C: The decimal 0.8 shows we have 8 in the tenths place value column so we can write this as 8/10. Both Tom and Katie have found equivalent fractions for 8/10. Tom has multiplied both the numerator and denominator by 10 (8/10 = 80/100) and Katie has divided both the numerator and denominator by 2 (8/10 = 4/5) so both are correct.
explanations.D: Start by finding out what 0.8 would be as a fraction. Use your knowledge of the place value to help you with this. Then see if you can multiply or divide the numerator and denominator of this fraction by the same value to get Tom or Katie's fraction.

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you have confused the place value after the decimal point. Think about the place value of the 6 in the decimal. Use this to write your fraction and then simplify if possible.
explanations.B: The decimal 0.6 shows we have 6 in the tenths place value column so we can write this as 6/10. Tom's fraction is 6/100 which would be the decimal 0.06 as we would have 6 in the hundredths column so Tom is incorrect. Katie has divided the numerator and denominator by 2 to get 6/10 = 3/5 so Katie has found an equivalent fraction and is correct.
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you have confused the place value after the decimal point. Remember that if they are both correct Tom and Katie's fractions would need to be equivalent to each other.
explanations.D: Start by finding out what 0.6 would be as a fraction. Use your knowledge of the place value to help you with this. Then see if you can multiply or divide the numerator and denominator of this fraction by the same value to get Tom or Katie's fraction.

explanations.A: We have 7 in the hundredths column which can be written as 7/100 and we have 3 in the tenths column which can be written as 3/10. 3/10 can be re-written as 30/100 as this is an equivalent fraction. If we add 7/100 and 30/100 together we get 37/100 so 0.37 is the same as 37/100.
explanations.B: This fraction has the value of 3.7 not 0.37. Think about what you would divide 37 by to get 0.37...
explanations.C: For this question, you need to use your knowledge of place value. What place value column is the 7 in? So, how can we write this as a fraction?
explanations.D: For this question, you need to use your knowledge of place value. What place value column is the 7 in? So, how can we write this as a fraction?

explanations.A: For this question, you need to use your knowledge of place value. What place value column is the 9 in? So, how can we write this as a fraction?
explanations.B: For this question, you need to use your knowledge of place value. What place value column is the 9 in? So, how can we write this as a fraction?
explanations.C: We have 9 in the hundredths place value column which can be written as 9/100 and we have 5 in the tenths column which can be written as 5/10. 5/10 can be re-written as 50/100 as this is an equivalent fraction. If we add 9/100 and 50/100 together we get 59/100 so 0.59 is the same as 59/100.
explanations.D: This fraction has the value of 5.9 not 0.59. Think about what you would divide 59 by to get 0.59...

explanations.A: 0.375 is 375 thousandths. Also try simplifying this fraction and see what you get.
explanations.B: Because the 5 in the decimal is in the thousandths column, we have 375 thousandths. How can you write this as a fraction?
explanations.C: 0.375 is 375 thousandths. = 375/1000. That means Tom is correct. If we divide the numerator and denominator by 125 we get 3/8, so Katie is correct.
explanations.D: At least one person is correct. Think about how you could write 375 thousandths as a fraction, and then simplify your answer as much as possible.

explanations.A: Because the 5 in the decimal is in the thousandths column, we have 625 thousandths. How can you write this as a fraction? Then also simplify your answer as much as possible.
explanations.B: Because the 5 in the decimal is in the thousandths column, we have 625 thousandths. How can you write this as a fraction? Then also simplify your answer as much as possible.
explanations.C: Because the 5 in the decimal is in the thousandths column, we have 625 thousandths. How can you write this as a fraction? Then also simplify your answer as much as possible.
explanations.D: 0.625 is 625 thousandths = 625/1000. This is not equivalent to 625/100 so Tom is incorrect. If we simplify this fraction (divide top and bottom by 125) we get 5/8, so Katie is incorrect.
